title: Loughcrew Walk Route

images.title: Rob Hurson, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Loughcrew Passage Tomb cairn T with another satellite tomb. Cairn T is one of the largest tombs in the complex. Inside it lies a cruciform chamber, a corbelled roof and some of the most beautiful examples of Neolithic art in Ireland. The cairn is aligned to sunrise at the spring and autumn equinoxes and at these times people gather there to greet the first rays of the sun.

images.title: Oliver Gargan, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

description: This historical walk visits the ancient tombs at Loughcrew near Oldcastle in County Meath. The ancient site includes a number of tombs thought to date to the 4th millennium BC. There is a parking area just to the west of the site. From here you can follow a path up to the top of the hill where you will find the cairns. There are some excellent views over the surrounding area from the elevated position. The hills and tombs collectively referred to as Slieve na Calliagh (Sliabh na Caillí) represent the highest point in Meath. This site is one of Ireland's four principal passage tomb cemeteries and is recognised as a protected National Monument. Additionally, the area encompasses the Loughcrew Estate, which lends its name to the site.
